propositions.text: Captain Crosbie emerges from the bank feeling pleased.
He is described as stout, ruddy, with a military moustache, and a swaggering gait.
He is described as jovial, good-natured, unmarried, and unremarkable.
He buys a newspaper on Bank Street.
He walks to Rashid Street, a main street parallel to the Tigris River.
He enters an office through a door with a brass plate.
A young Iraqi clerk greets Captain Crosbie.
He asks if Mr. Dakin is in his office.
Captain Crosbie enters Mr. Dakin's office.
The room is high-ceilinged, sparse, with a primus stove, a low divan, and a shabby table.
Mr. Dakin appears weary and indecisive.
Dakin asks Crosbie if he's just arrived from Kirkuk.
Crosbie nods and closes the door.
The door is revealed to be soundproof.
With the door closed, their demeanour changes; Dakin is revealed to be the superior.
Crosbie asks for news.
Dakin sighs and points to a telegram he was translating.
Dakin states the meeting will be held in Baghdad.
He burns the telegram.
Dakin confirms the meeting is in Baghdad for the 20th of the next month and emphasizes 'absolute secrecy'.
Crosbie mentions the matter has been discussed in the market for three days.
Dakin expresses that there are no secrets in the East.
Crosbie questions if the meeting will really happen, specifically if 'Uncle Joe' will attend.
Dakin believes 'Uncle Joe' will attend.
Dakin suggests an 'understanding' could resolve everything.
Crosbie expresses doubt about achieving any understanding.
Dakin suggests that bringing together opposing ideologies might only deepen suspicion.
Dakin mentions a third factor: a 'fantastic' story by Carmichael.
Crosbie dismisses Carmichael's story as too fantastic.
Dakin recounts his initial disbelief, thinking either Carmichael or the story was not to be trusted.
Dakin states Carmichael believes the story and has evidence.
Carmichael is going to Baghdad to investigate and obtain proof.
Dakin questions the wisdom of sending Carmichael and if he will return.
Crosbie exclaims about 'proof'.
Dakin confirms Carmichael has proof.
Dakin explains he knows about the proof due to a prearranged code: 'The camel with the oats is crossing the pass.'
This message was relayed by Sarah Hassan.
Carmichael obtained what he needed but is now suspected and being watched.
He is being watched at the border and ambushed around embassies and consulates.
Dakin shows Crosbie documents detailing recent killings of individuals matching Carmichael's description.
These include a British man shot by brigands, a Kurdish merchant ambushed, and a Kurdish smuggler shot by police.
The killers are willing to kill innocent people to get to Carmichael.
The danger increases once Carmichael reaches Iraq, with potential informers at embassies, consulates, airports, customs, stations, and hotels.
Crosbie raises his eyebrows at the extensive network.
Dakin confirms his suspicion, citing that even their own operations have leaks.
Crosbie asks if Dakin suspects anyone.
Dakin shakes his head slowly.
Crosbie sighs and asks if they will proceed.
Dakin confirms they will proceed.
Crosbie asks about Crofton Lee.
Dakin states Crofton Lee has agreed to come to Baghdad.
Crosbie notes that everyone is coming to Baghdad, including 'Uncle Joe', and expresses concern about potential unrest if the president has an accident.
Dakin insists nothing can go wrong and it is their duty to ensure it.
After Crosbie leaves, Dakin murmurs 'They have arrived in Baghdad...'
He draws a circle with 'Baghdad' inside, surrounded by a camel, airplane, ship, and train.
He draws a spiderweb with 'Anna Schiller' in the center and a large question mark below.
Dakin leaves his office.
On Rashid Street, someone inquires about him and describes him as working for an oil company, being a good man but never getting promoted, lacking drive, and unlikely to get ahead.
Victoria Jones sits glumly in Regent's Park, contemplating the damage caused by misplaced talent.
She is described as having virtues (generous, enthusiastic, brave) and faults (prone to lying).
Her lies are fluent, natural, and artistic.
She prefers fabricating elaborate stories to simple excuses.
She wishes for a world with elephants on traffic lines and dangerous men in streets.
Despite being slender and well-proportioned, Victoria has a plain face.
A former admirer called her face a 'little rubber face' capable of mimicry.
This mimicry led to her current predicament.
She works as a typist for Messrs. Grinholtz, Siemens, and Ledbert.
She was bored and imitated Mrs. Grinholtz to her colleagues.
She believed Mr. Grinholtz was visiting his solicitor and felt safe to perform.
Her performance is interrupted when Mr. Grinholtz appears at the door.
Her colleagues suddenly return to their work.
Victoria can only exclaim, 'Oh, my!'
Mr. Grinholtz grunts and enters his office, closing the door and ringing a bell for Victoria.
Her colleagues taunt her about being in trouble.
The office boy makes a throat-cutting gesture.
Victoria, maintaining a composed demeanor, enters Mr. Grinholtz's office.
She asks if he summoned her.
Mr. Grinholtz states he's tired of her and intends to pay her a week's salary and dismiss her immediately.
He asks if she has any reason why he shouldn't.
Victoria, an orphan whose meager salary supports her ill mother, initially considers explaining.
Seeing Mr. Grinholtz's unpleasant face, she changes her mind.
Victoria cheerfully agrees with him, stating he is 100% correct if he knew her true meaning.
Mr. Grinholtz is surprised by her agreement and counts coins, finding he is short ninepence.
Victoria kindly suggests he use the money for a cinema or sweets.
Mr. Grinholtz notes the absence of stamps, and Victoria says she never writes letters.
He mentions he'll send her the money later, but Victoria asks for a letter of dismissal instead.
Mr. Grinholtz angrily asks why he should write a letter of dismissal.
Victoria states it is natural.

Mr. Grinholtz scribbles a dismissive letter stating Victoria was employed for two months, her shorthand was inaccurate, she made spelling mistakes, and was dismissed for not working during office hours.
Victoria calls it a 'very bad testimonial'.
Mr. Grinholtz retorts he did not write it as one.
Victoria suggests he should at least mention her honesty, diligence, and propriety, perhaps adding 'careful'.
Mr. Grinholtz shouts 'Careful?!'
Victoria calmly repeats 'Careful.'
Recalling her transcribed letters, Mr. Grinholtz decides caution is better than resentment.
He tears up the first letter and rewrites it, stating Victoria left due to redundancy.
Victoria finds it acceptable, though it could be better.
Victoria, with a week's salary (minus ninepence), sits on a bench in Regent's Park.
She habitually eats a simple lunch from a cold-meat counter in the park.
She reflects on considering time and place, and that mimicking the boss's wife was inappropriate.
She believes she will find another job and is optimistic about the future.
She throws breadcrumbs to sparrows and notices a young man on the other end of the bench.
She finds him handsome, angelic, with a determined chin and striking blue eyes.
She suspects he has been admiring her.
Victoria smiles at him, and he responds as if by a string.
He asks if she often visits the park.
She replies almost daily.
He regrets not having come before and asks if she has finished lunch.
He suggests they go for sausages.
Victoria declines, stating she is not hungry.
She expects him to suggest another time, but he introduces himself as Edward and asks her name.
She is Victoria, and he questions why her family gave her a station name.
Victoria corrects him, mentioning Queen Victoria.
He asks her surname, which is Jones.
Edward comments that Victoria Jones doesn't flow well.
Victoria agrees and suggests names like 'Victoria Sackville-West' for more elegance.
They playfully suggest adding names before Jones, like 'Bedford Jones' and 'Cadisbrooke Jones'.
Edward checks his watch, exclaiming he must return to his boss.
He asks Victoria what she does.
Victoria replies she is unemployed, having been fired that morning.
Edward expresses sympathy.
Victoria states she isn't sorry as she can easily find another job and finds the situation amusing.
She recounts the morning's events, including mimicking Mrs. Grinholtz.
Edward is highly entertained and delayed from returning to his boss.
Edward calls her wonderful and suggests she should be on the stage.
Victoria advises him to leave if he doesn't want to be fired.
Edward expresses envy for her secretarial skills.
Victoria admits she's not an excellent typist but explains that even poor typists can find work in educational or charitable institutions that cannot afford high salaries.
She prefers academic work due to the complexity of scientific terms making errors less embarrassing.
She asks about his job and guesses he is recently demobilized from the RAF.
Edward confirms and then guesses she guessed correctly about being a fighter pilot.
He explains the RAF found him a job, but he feels they don't need intelligent people.
He is placed in an office doing data and numerical work, finding it aimless and making him feel useless.
He laments not being able to connect with the work, contrasting it with the high purpose of wartime combat, where he received the DFC.
Victoria feels sympathy for him.
Edward further elaborates on feeling useless and wanting to leave.
He pulls out a small camera and asks to take a snapshot of Victoria.
He reveals he is going to Baghdad tomorrow.
Victoria exclaims in disappointment.
Edward explains he was happy to go that morning, wanting to leave the country.
He describes his job as dealing with 'culture and poetry'.
His boss, Dr. Raisborn, is a reformer who is opening bookstores, including one in Baghdad.
Dr. Raisborn is translating Shakespeare and Milton into Arabic, Kurdish, Persian, and Armenian.
Edward finds this foolish, similar to the British Council's efforts, but acknowledges he has a job and shouldn't complain.
Victoria asks what his actual duties are.
Edward describes himself as a subordinate, running errands, booking tickets, filling out forms, packing manuscripts, and generally doing odd jobs.
He believes it's a 'goodwill movement' for youth reform.
He confesses the work is taxing.
Victoria cannot offer encouraging words.
Edward asks Victoria to pose for the camera.
He takes two photos.
Victoria feels pleased and self-satisfied.
Edward regrets having to leave so soon after meeting her.
He is conflicted about going but has already completed the paperwork and visas.
He asks if she thinks the work will be pleasant.
Victoria suggests it might not be as bad as he imagines.
Edward expresses doubt and a strange feeling that something is suspicious.
He compares it to a past experience with engine oil where a washer was misplaced.
Victoria asks if he thinks Dr. Raisborn is a fake.
Edward can't say, describing Dr. Raisborn as respectable, learned, and associated with important figures.
He reiterates it's just a feeling, and time will tell.
He bids farewell, hoping she might also come.
Victoria expresses hope that she will go too.
Edward asks about her plans.
Victoria states she is going to St. Gilderick's office on High Holborn to look for work.
Edward says goodbye, quoting 'Separation is a death' in English.
He criticizes the English for their mawkish goodbyes.
Victoria bids him luck.
Edward says she won't miss him.
Victoria says she will.
Edward notes she is different from other girls and then rushes off as the clock strikes.
Victoria remains on the bench, deep in thought.
She has two clear trains of thought: one related to Romeo and Juliet.
She feels their situation is similar: instant attraction, setbacks, and parting.
She recalls a nursery rhyme about Jumblo and Alice.
She relates 'America' in the rhyme to Baghdad.
Victoria stands up, brushes off crumbs, and leaves the park.
She makes two decisions: she has fallen in love with Edward and intends to marry him.
Her only way to achieve this is to go to Baghdad, where Edward is going.
She is confident this can be achieved due to her optimistic and determined nature.
She feels the same intensity of emotion about parting as Edward.
Victoria declares to herself, 'I must get to Baghdad!'
Anna Schiller is received with warmth at the Savoy Hotel as a regular customer.
They inquire about Mr. Morgensell's health and assure her of satisfactory accommodation.
Anna Schiller is presented as a representative of dollars.
After showering and changing, Schiller calls a place in Kensington and takes a taxi to Cartier's jewelry shop on Bond Street.
As Schiller's taxi leaves the Savoy, a short, dark-faced man watching a shop window checks his watch and hails a taxi.
This taxi, which passes by a frantic woman with a package, is taken by the man.
Schiller's taxi travels down the Strand, maintaining a distance from the second taxi, which follows within sight.
At Trafalgar Square, the second taxi signals from its left window while stopped at a red light.
A private car parked near the Admiralty Arch starts up and joins the traffic behind the second taxi.
Schiller's car turns left towards Pall Mall.
The dark-faced man's taxi turns right, continuing around Trafalgar Square.
The grey Standard car now follows Schiller's taxi.
It contains a fair-faced, somewhat vacant young man driving and a well-dressed young woman beside him.
The Standard car follows Schiller's taxi down Piccadilly and onto Bond Street.
The car suddenly brakes, and the young woman gets out, saying 'Thank you very much.'
She walks on, glancing into windows, and crosses to Cartier's jewelry shop.
Anna Schiller pays for her taxi and enters Cartier's.
She selects a sapphire and diamond ring and writes a check from a London bank.
The jeweler becomes extremely attentive upon seeing her name.
He greets her, asks about Mr. Morgensell, and offers to show her a valuable sapphire he knows Mr. Morgensell is interested in.
Schiller agrees to look at the sapphire.
She expresses admiration and promises to tell Mr. Morgensell.
She leaves Cartier's and walks along Bond Street.
The young woman, who was pretending to decide on earrings, also leaves the shop.
The grey Standard car, which had turned left on Grafton Street and gone to Piccadilly Circus, reappears on Bond Street.
The young woman pretends not to see it.
Anna Schiller turns into Arcade Street and enters a florist's.
She orders three dozen long-stemmed roses, a large violet, a dozen lilac branches, and a vase of mimosa.
She leaves an address for delivery and pays £12 18s.
The young woman enters and asks the price of a bunch of primroses but does not buy them.
Schiller walks across Bond Street, down Burlington Street, and into Savile Row, entering a tailor's shop.
Mr. Burford greets her and discusses fabrics.
He mentions using export cloth and asks when she returns to New York.
She replies the 23rd and he assures her it will be ready for her flight.
Mr. Burford comments on the poor state of England compared to America.
He praises the tailor, Mr. Lantwick, his only reliable employee.
He emphasizes British quality and craftsmanship, contrasting it with mass production.
He suggests she try on the clothes next week.
Anna Schiller walks out into the street.
She hails a taxi back to the Savoy Hotel.
Another taxi, with the short, dark-faced man, drives past the Savoy, picks up a stout woman from the hotel entrance, and heads towards the Embankment.
The stout woman asks 'How is it, Louisa? Was her room searched?'
Louisa replies, 'Searched, and nothing found.'
Anna Schiller has lunch in the restaurant, at a window table reserved for her.
The head waiter inquires about Otto Morgensell's health.
After lunch, Schiller returns to her room.
The room is tidied, and new towels are provided.
She checks an unlocked suitcase and then unlocks another.
Everything appears undisturbed.
Her brief case is on top, with a small Leica camera and two film rolls still sealed.
She notices a single golden hair on the briefcase, smiles, and removes it.
She dusts the briefcase with powder and wipes it clean, removing any fingerprints.
She reflects that it should have had her own fingerprints from earlier that morning.
She smiles again, muttering, 'Well done, but not quite professional enough...'
She packs a small overnight bag and takes a taxi to 16 Elmsleyve Road, Kensington.
At Elmsleyve Road, an elderly woman answers the door with surprise, then a welcoming smile.
She says Miss Els will be delighted to see her and is in the study, her mood improved by the anticipation of her visit.
Anna enters a small, old, but comfortable room with armchairs.
A woman sitting in a chair jumps up, exclaiming 'Anna, darling!'
Anna replies, 'Els.'
They kiss affectionately.
Els says, 'Everything is arranged. I'm moving in tonight.'
Anna assures her, 'Don't worry, everything will be fine.'
The short, dark-faced man enters a public telephone booth near Kensington High Street station.
He dials and asks for the 'Wilhalara Gramophone Company.'
He identifies himself as 'Saunders' from the Tigris.
He reports on A.S. (Anna Schiller), who arrived from New York that morning.
He details her visits to Cartier's (a £120 ring), Jenny Cant's florist (£12 18s for flowers sent to a private hospital), and Burford and Ivory's tailor (suit and skirt ordered).
He notes no suspicious links to these businesses but advises continued attention.
He reports A.S.'s Savoy room was searched with no findings.
Her briefcase contained publicly available merger documents with Wolfenstein and a camera with two unexposed film rolls, possibly for direct copying or substitution.
A.S. took a small travel bag to her sister at 16 Elmsleyve Road, Kensington.
Her sister is to stay at the private hospital in Portland Square tonight for internal surgery, confirmed by hospital records.
A.S.'s visit appears open and without suspicion of being followed.
She will spend the night at the hospital, and her Savoy room is retained.
She has booked a return flight to New York for the 23rd.
Saunders adds his opinion that it's all a sham, citing her extravagant spending on flowers.
Victoria, with her characteristic optimism, doesn't consider the possibility of failure.
She has fallen in love with the charismatic young man, Edward, who is leaving for Baghdad.
She resolves to find a way to go to Baghdad, despite the difficulties.
Victoria walks along Tottenham Court Road, considering how to get to Baghdad.
Edward mentioned his work is 'cultural'.
She wonders if she could find work with UNESCO, but acknowledges such positions are usually for highly qualified graduates.
She visits a travel agency to inquire about travel to Baghdad.
Options include flying, sea travel to Basra, train to Marseilles then ship to Beirut and desert crossing, or via Egypt.
A continuous train journey is possible but obtaining a visa is difficult and uncertain.
Baghdad is in the sterling area, so money is not an issue regarding currency exchange.
The main requirement is £60-£100 in cash.
Victoria only has £3 10s (minus 9d), plus £0 12s, and £5 in her savings bank.
Therefore, paying for the trip herself is impossible.
She asks about jobs as a stewardess or waitress, but anticipates high competition.
Victoria visits St. Gilderick's office, where Miss Spencer greets her with familiarity, assuming she's lost her job again.
Victoria asserts it was difficult to stay and implies suffering.
Miss Spencer, blushing with pleasure, begins to comment on Mr. Grinholtz's behavior.
Victoria cuts her off, saying she can take care of herself, with a forced smile.
Miss Spencer consults her notebook and mentions the St. Leonard's Benevolent Association for Unmarried Mothers needs a typist, with a low salary.
Victoria impulsively asks if there's a possibility of finding a job in Baghdad.
Miss Spencer is astonished.
Victoria states her strong desire to go to Baghdad.
Miss Spencer asks if she means a secretarial position.
Victoria says any job would do: nurse, cook, or companion to a mentally ill person.
Miss Spencer shakes her head, mentioning a woman who wanted to buy a plane ticket to Australia for her two daughters.

concepts.name: Captain Crosbie
concepts.context: An Englishman described at the beginning of the story, a character with a jovial disposition and a military bearing.

concepts.name: Baghdad
concepts.context: The primary setting for a significant upcoming meeting and a destination for several characters.

concepts.name: Mr. Dakin
concepts.context: A weary and indecisive man who appears to be in charge of a secret operation concerning a meeting in Baghdad.

concepts.name: Meeting
concepts.context: A planned event in Baghdad, the details of which are secret and involve high-level political figures.

concepts.name: Secrecy
concepts.context: A key element surrounding the meeting in Baghdad, with emphasis on its difficulty in the East.

concepts.name: Carmichael
concepts.context: A character involved in a 'fantastic' story and possessing crucial 'proof' related to the Baghdad meeting.

concepts.name: Proof
concepts.context: Something Carmichael possesses and is going to Baghdad to retrieve or present.

concepts.name: Edward
concepts.context: A charming young man Victoria meets in the park, who is about to travel to Baghdad for a cultural job.

concepts.name: Victoria Jones
concepts.context: A young woman who loses her job and becomes infatuated with Edward, resolving to go to Baghdad.

concepts.name: Job
concepts.context: A recurring theme for Victoria, who has recently lost hers and is actively seeking new employment.

concepts.name: Anna Schiller
concepts.context: A mysterious woman arriving from New York, seemingly involved in business and intelligence operations, who also travels to Baghdad.

concepts.name: Travel
concepts.context: A significant theme, with characters planning or undertaking journeys to various locations, most notably Baghdad.

concepts.name: Surveillance
concepts.context: Implied and explicit observation of characters, particularly Anna Schiller and Carmichael, by unknown parties.

concepts.name: Diplomacy
concepts.context: Underlying the planned meeting in Baghdad, with discussions of 'understanding' and resolving ideological differences.

concepts.name: Intelligence
concepts.context: Suggested by the coded messages, surveillance, and the search of Anna Schiller's belongings.

concepts.name: Misdirection
concepts.context: Anna Schiller's actions of buying flowers and ordering clothes may be a form of misdirection or cover.

concepts.name: Lying
concepts.context: A prominent trait of Victoria, who fabricates stories, and also hinted at in the deceptive actions of some characters.

concepts.name: Optimism
concepts.context: A defining characteristic of Victoria, who believes she can overcome any obstacle.

concepts.name: Suspicion
concepts.context: A recurring element, both in Dakin's feeling about Dr. Raisborn and in the general atmosphere of espionage.

concepts.name: Money
concepts.context: A practical consideration for travel, and also a symbol of power and influence (Anna Schiller as a 'representative of dollars').

concepts.name: London
concepts.context: The initial setting for several characters before their journeys, a place of employment and social interactions.

concepts.name: New York
concepts.context: Anna Schiller's origin and destination, implying international connections.

concepts.name: Culture
concepts.context: Edward's stated purpose for going to Baghdad, and a theme of Dr. Raisborn's endeavors.

main_topics: Victoria's Pursuit of Love and Adventure
hierarchy.structure: The document is structured into chapters, each focusing on different sets of characters and their interwoven storylines, converging towards the impending meeting in Baghdad. Chapter 1 introduces the intrigue surrounding the meeting. Chapter 2 follows Victoria's personal journey and her decision to go to Baghdad. Chapter 3 details Anna Schiller's activities and hints at her covert operations. Chapter 4 shows Victoria's preparations and determination to reach Baghdad.
